chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: Stool is a command line tool that provides a lifecycle for stages: create, configure, build, run and remove. A stage contains web applications, that may come in different flavors: Maven war projects or artifacts (GAV coordinates). Here's an example, what you can do with stool:
(The following assumes that Stool has been installed properly - see the respective section below)
Invoke stool to see if stool is installed. You should get a usage message with available commands.

Create a new stage by checking out an application:
stool create https://github.com/mlhartme/hellowar/trunk
Build the application:
stool build
Start it:
stool start
To see the running application, point your browser to the url printed by the start command.

You can invoke
stool status
to see if your application is running and to see the application urls.

To remove the stage, stop the application with
stool stop
and dump it from your disk with
stool remove

You can create an arbitrary number of stages. Invoke stool list
to see what you have created and not yet removed. To switch to another stage, invoke
stool select otherstage
You can use
stool history
to see what happend on the stage.

sect1.title: Stage
sect1.para:
hosts one or more web applications. A stage has a
directory
Where the stage is stored in your file system. This is where you usually work with your stage. It holds the source code or the artifacts of this stage. The directory is specified when you create a stage. You can change the stage directory with 'stool move'.
name
Unique identifier for a stage. The name of the selected stage is shown in your shell prompt, you use it to switch between stages, and it's part of the application urls. In most cases, you create a stage without specifying a name, and the name is automatically derived from the directory; you'll get an error message if it's not unique. You can change the name with 'stool rename'.
url
Specifies where the web applications come from: A Subversion URL or Maven Coordinates. Examples https://github.com/mlhartme/hellowar/trunk gav:net.oneandone:hellowar:1.0.1
type
How the stage contains the web application(s): source - checkout of a Maven project, or artifact - a Maven artifact.
state
one of
down: initial state or after stage was stopped
up: state after successful start or restart
sleeping: state after stage was stopped with '-sleep'
owner
see below

sect1.title: Selected stage and stage indicator
sect1.para: Usually you have one stage you're working with: the selected stage, which is shown in the stage indicator in your prompt:{somestage}. After creating a stage, it automatically becomes the selected stage, subsequent Stool commands work with this stage. If you want wo work with a different stage, you use 'stool select' to switch to it. When you remove the current stage, you no longer have a selected stage and the stage indicator vanishes.

Note that you do not have to select a stage before you can work with it - you can use selection options instead. For example, 'stool status -stage foo' prints the status of stage 'foo', no matter what stage you have currently selected.

sect1.title: Stage commands
sect1.para: Most Stool commands are stage commands, i.e. they operate on (an arbitary number of) stages. Typical stage commands are 'status', 'build', 'start', and 'stop'. Note that 'create' is not a stage command because it does not have a stage to operate on (although it results in a new (and selected) stage).

By default, stage commands operate on the selected stage. You can change this by specifying one of the selection options '-all', '-all-state <state>', '-all-owner <owner>' or '-stage <name>'. E.g. 'stool status -all-owner mhm' prints the status of all stages owned by user 'mhm'. Or you can print the configuration of stage 'foo' with 'stool config -stage foo' without changing the selected stage.

Stage commands have a failure mode, configurable with '-fail <mode>', to specify how to deal with broken stages and failed stage commands. Mode 'normal' reports problems as soon as they are detected; this is the default. 'after' reports problems after the actual command was invoked on all selected stages. And finally 'never' is similar to 'after', but reports warnings instead of errors (and thus, stool always returns with a success error code).

sect1.title: Stage owner
sect1.para: To comply with company security rules, Stool can run in shared mode. If you run Stool on your own machine and you are the only user, you'll set 'shared' to false - you can skip the rest of this section. On this other hand, if Stool is used by multiple users, you'll used shared mode as described below.

If you create a new stage, you become the owner of this stage. You own the files in the stage directory in terms of Unix file ownership, and you have write access to stage files. Other users have read access to the files. Note that everybody (with the appropriate svn permissions) can change files in Subversion, but only the stage owner can run 'svn up' on his stage. Note also, that everybody can change files via Pustefix Editor (with the appropriate editor permissions), they appear as modified by the stage owner), but only the stage owner can commit the modifications.
Starting a stage starts a Tomcat process owned by the stage owner, no matter who actually issued the start command. Any user can start and stop a stage, not only the owner.
If a different user has to make changes to stage files, he/she has to use the 'chown' command to become owner of the stage and thus get the necessary permissions to change files.

Example: If user 'mhm' owns stage 'tec1584', and user 'bitterichc' wants to change a file in the stage directory, one of them has to run 'stool chown -stage tec1584 bitterichc'. This will stop any stage processes (which is allowed for bitterichc as well!), change Unix file ownership of the stage files to 'bitterichc' and re-start the stage processes to also change process ownership to the new owner..

Rationale:
Tool users like 'servlet' or 'stage5' have to be replaced by personalized logins (security guideline). We need to know exactly who changed a stage file (security guideline). It's difficult and fragile to grant multiple users write access to stage files (e.g. via umask configuration), in particular because the respective user's home directories have to be private.
Ownership is meant to track changes, not to prevent them.

Implementation note: The chown command internally uses sudo to elevate the current user's permissions to start/stop processes or change file ownership. Note that some files have to be group-writable, because arbitrary users have to create them: the global lock and things generated by stool start). All users of stool have to be in the same group.

sect1.title: Stage wrapper
sect1.para: Every stage directory as an associated wrapper - a directory that stores Stool-related data about the stage, e.g. the stage properties or the Tomcat configuration. The wrapper is created when you create or import the stage. Wrapper directories are created in '$STOOL_HOME/wrappers' and have the name of the stage; Stool uses this directory to iterate all stages.

Stool removes wrappers either explicitly when you invoke the 'remove' command, or implicitly when it detects a stale wrapper. A wrapper is stale if its corresponding stage directory has been deleted (usually by a user running 'rm -rf' on it. Stool checks for - and cleans - stale wrappers before every command. Cleaning a stale wrapper deletes (kill -9) all processes that have a pid file in the wrapper directory and deletes the wrapper itself.

sect1.title: Stage expiring
sect1.para: Every stage has an 'until' property that specifies how long the stage is needed. You can see the until date with 'stool config until'. If this date has passed, the stage is automatically stopped and you cannot start it unless you specify a new date with 'stool config until=yyyy-mm-dd'. The stage owner gets an email notification if his stage expired. And after 5 notifications, the ovners team lead is CCed in this mail. This mechanism helps to detect and remove unused stages, which is crucial for shared machines. If you receive an email notification that you stage has expired, please check if your stage is still needed. If so, adjust the until data, otherwise remove the stage.

sect1.title: System commands
sect1.para: Commands that do not deal with individual stages.

sect2.title: system-start
sect2.para: Starts that the stage overview. If -awake is given, system-start will also awake all sleeping stages.

sect2.title: system-stop
sect2.para: Stops the overview. If -sleep is given, system-stop will also send all stages to sleep.

sect2.title: system-validate
sect2.para: Checks the system configuration like DNS settings.

sect1.title: Create
sect1.para: Creates a new stage directory from the specified url, enters the directory and selects the stage. In most cases, you invoke 'stool create' similar to 'svn checkout': with an url and a directory.

In many cases, the url is a subversion url and Stool performs a checkout and creates the wrapper directory. Output of the checkout command is printed to the console unless the quiet option is specified.
The new stage is configured with default stage properties. You can specify key-value pairs to override the defaults, or you can change the configuration later with 'stool config'.
If directory is not specified, that current directory with last segment of the url is used.
Unless specified with the '-name' option, the stage name is the directory name.
Instead of a <url,> you can specify '% <searchstring>'. This will search Pommes for the specified search string, show all corresponding svn urls (including branches), and ask you to select one.
Create reports an error if the available free disk space is low (the threshold is specified in the Stool configuration.

sect1.title: Build
sect1.para: Enters the stage directory and executes the build command specified in the 'build' property.
You can see the build command with 'stool config build', and you can change it with 'stool config "build=command to build"' (the quotes are mandatory if your command contains spaces).

'stool build' does no extra magic besides entering the stage directory and executing the build command. It has exactly the same effect if you invoke the build command yourself, without Stool. 'stool build' is only for your convenience, you do not have to use it to build you project properly.

The build command execute in the same environment (i.e. with the same environment variablens) as Stool is executed. If you invoke 'build' from the overview application, the build command executes in the environment of the user who started the overview.

sect1.title: Remove
sect1.para: Removes the stage, i.e. deletes the stage directory and the wrapper directory.

Before removing anything, this command checks if there are uncommitted changes or if the stage is started. If so, the command is aborted with an error. In this case, stop the Stage and inspect the uncommitted changes; either commit them or revert them. Alternatively, you can disable this check with the -force option.
Also, before removing anything, this command asks if you really want to remove the stage. You can disable this check with the -batch option.
If you specify the -wrapper option, only the wrapper directory will be deleted. This is useful to "unimport" a stage, i.e. revert the effect or 'stool import'.

sect1.title: Start
sect1.para: Creates the necessary configuration and starts Tomcat. If the stage is an artifact stage, you can start it right away; otherwise, you have to build it first. Depending on your application, startup may take a while; you can check catalina.out to verify if start is complete: 'stool cd logs && tail -f catalina.out'
'-debug' and '-suspend' enable the debugger. The difference is that suspend waits for the debugger to connect before starting any application code.
Use the '-tail' option to get catalina.out printed to the console until you press ctrl-c.
Startup is refused if your stage has expired. In this case, use 'stool config until=newdata' to configure a new 'until' date.

The Tomcat version is configurable with 'stool config tomcat.version=<version>'. You have to restart the stage when you change the version. The respective Tomcat will be downloaded automatically to '$STOOL_HOME/tomcat/downloads'. Alternatively, you can place customized Tomcats into this directory, provided they unpack to a directory that matches the base file name of the tar.gz file.
Start generates a Tomcat base directory if it does not yet exist. If it exists, only the server.xml is updated by taking server.xml.template and adding all apps to it.

The environment of the started application is the current environment restricted to the variables listed in the 'tomcat.env' property; variables listed there are passed to the application, all others are removed. If you invoke 'start' from the overview application, the user who started the overview defines the basic environment, not the owner of the stage.

sect1.title: Select
sect1.para: Jumps between stages, marks the current stage and updates environment variables.
Prints the current stage when called without argument.

Changes the selected stage when called with an stage name:
Adjusts the environment variables for the selected stage (e.g. MAVEN_OPTS, JAVA_HOME).
Changes the current working directory to the stage directory.
Adjusts the selected stage indicator. If it's red, you're not the owner.
When called with 'none': resets environment variables and removes that stage indicator.
If the specified stage is not found, the command prints an error message and lists stages that you could have meant.
Note that you cannot properly switch to a different stage with 'cd' because the environment (e.g. JAVA_HOME, MAVEN_OPTS) will not be updated for the new stage.

sect1.title: Cd
sect1.para:
Changes the current working directory to the specified target:
(empty): the stage directory
wrapper: the stage's wrapper directory.
(otherwise): the specified direct or indirect sub-directory of the wrapper directory.
Example: 'stool cd logs' will change to shared/tomcat/logs inside your wrapper.

sect1.title: Config
sect1.para: Gets or sets properties. A property is a key-value pair that configures the respective stage.
When invoked without arguments, all properties are printed with documentation.
When invoked with one or more keys, the respective properties are printed. Example: 'stool config tomcat.heap' prints the current value for the tomcat.heap property.
When invoked with one or more assignments, the respective properties are changed. Example: 'stool config tomcat.heap=1000' sets the tomcat heap size to 1000 mb.

If you want to set a property to a value with spaces, you have to use quotes around the key-value pair. Otherwise, the shell does not see what belongs to your value. Example: 'stool config "build=mvn clean package"'
If you change a property, you have to invoke the necessary re-builds or re-starts to make the changes effective.
Date properties have the form 'yyyy-mm-dd', so a valid date is - e.g. - 2013-12-31.

Values in list properties (e.g. 'tomcat.select') are separated by commas. Example: 'stool config tomcat.select=foo,bar'. Do not used spaces around the comma because the shell would consider this as a new key-value argument -- unless you also quote the arguments.

sect1.title: Rename
sect1.para: Changes the stage name without touching anything else. If the stage is up, you have to restart it to reflect this change in your application urls.

sect1.title: Move
sect1.para: Moves the stage directory. If dest exists, it is moved into it. Otherwise it is moved into the parent of dest with the specified name. This is the same behavior as the unix 'mv' command, but it also adjusts Stool's wrapper directory.

sect1.title: Import
sect1.para: Scans the specified directories (recursively) for new stages and offers to import them. If the scan only yields a single candidate, it will be imported and selected without additional interaction. Importing means that a wrapper directory for the stage directory is created.

sect1.title: Install
sect1.para: To install Stool on your system (skip this if your working on a stage - Stool is readily installed there):

listitem.para: Download Stool's application file and store it at '/YOUR/DOWNLOADS/setup-stool'.
Option: Stool will be configured to use 'java' as found in your $PATH when 'stool-setup' is executed. If you want to use a different Java version, make sure to adjust your $PATH accordingly.

Actually install Stool: run '/YOUR/DOWNLOADS/setup-stool /PATH/TO/STOOL/HOME'. This will create Stool's home directory at the specified location. It's good practice home make major and minor version part of this path.
Add the lines 'source STOOL/HOME/PATH/bin/stool-function' to your $HOME/.bashrc file. This defines the shell function 'stool' that operates on the $STOOL_HOME directory.
Adjust Stool configuration file '$STOOL_HOME/config.json' to your needs.
Open a new shell window to make sure that your modified bashrc is loaded.
Invoke 'stool' to verify your setup. You should get a usage message.
Setup-stool is no longer needed, remove it with 'rm /YOUR/DOWNLOADS/setup-stool'

sect1.para: Implementation note: 'stool' is a shell function, so 'which stool' cannot find it (you can see if with 'declare'). 'stool' is not a binary because it has to adjust your environment variables (e.g. to set MAVEN_OPTS depending on you current stage) - this is possible in a shell function, but not in a binary.
There's no uninstall command. To uninstall Stool:

listitem.para: Remove the initialization code from your shell files.

sect1.title: Upgrade
sect1.para: If you run a new 'stool-setup' on an existing $STOOL_HOME it perform an incremental or full upgrade. An incremental upgrade just updates 'stool.jar', it is used if only the micro version number has changed. A full upgrade is performed if the minor or major version of Stool has changed. In this case, a new $STOOL_HOME directory is creatend and the configuration and all stages from the old home directory is imported (shows a diff before changing anything). You can remove the old home directory after a full upgrade when you no longer need the old log files.

Here's the best practice to roll-out a new version (unless it's only an incremental upgrade) on a machine:
Run 'validate -all' and fix possible problems Make sure there are no other shells open when you run setup-stool. This is crucial because existing shells (in particular those of other users!) continue to access the old stool version, and this will usually cause problems with the upgraded home directory.
'stool system-stop' Run 'setup-stool' and adjust you shell initialization code.
Login with a new shell to get the updated Stool version and run the following commands - but keep the original shell open until the commands succeeded:
'stool validate -all' 'stool system-start'

chapter.title: Directory Layout
chapter.para:
... of a source stage
(stage directory) (normal application files) (stool home) |- config.json (Stool configuration) |- downloads |- bin | |- stool-function | |- service-wrapper.sh | |- stool.jar | |- stool-(timestamp).jar (optional incremental updates) | |- stool-catalina.sh | '- stool-chown.sh |- inbox (to push jars into artifact stages with an inbox urls) |- extensions (for jars with Stool extensions) |- logs | |- stool.log | |- (archived stool logs) |- overview (stage directory of the overview stage) |- service-wrapper |- conf | |- stool.lock | |- sleep.json | '- users | |- (one file per user session) | : |- tomcat | |- apache-tomcat-7.0.59 | : '- wrappers '- (stage name) |- config.json (stage properties and some status fields) |- anchor (symlink to stage directory) |- ports (ports allocated for this stage -- created when stage is first started) '- shared |- buildstats.json |- ssl (generated certs, if any) |- run (pid stuff for service wrapper) |- conf | '- service-wrapper.conf '- tomcat (tomcat for this stage) |- conf (standard tomcat directory with generated server.xml) |- temp (standart tomcat) |- work (standard tomcat) '- logs '- applogs (application log files for pustefix apps)
